review.title: Prioritised Default Logic as Argumentation with Partial Order Default Priorities
review.abstract: We express Brewka's prioritised default logic (PDL) as argumentation using ASPIC+. By representing PDL as argumentation and designing an argument preference relation that takes the argument structure into account, we prove that the conclusions of the justified arguments correspond to the PDL extensions. We will first assume that the default priority is total, and then generalise to the case where it is a partial order. This provides a characterisation of non-monotonic inference in PDL as an exchange of argument and counter-argument, providing a basis for distributed non-monotonic reasoning in the form of dialogue.

sections.heading: 4.4 Summary
sections.text: In this section, we have generalized our solid and complete instantiation of ASPIC + to PDL to the extent that the default priority is not necessarily an overall order. The main challenge is to generalize SP argument preference -SP from a total default priority to a partial default priority. We design a sort F (< D) = < SP so that < SP < D sorts the argument structure, the failed rule preference < D, and the incomparability of rules (Section 4.1) in a way that respects the consistency between the conclusions of the underlying PDT and the conclusions of legitimate arguments (Section 4.2, sentence 4.11). We have also shown that any stable extension fulfills the postulated rationality (Section 4.3, sentence 4.12).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: We have provided Brewka's PDL [7] with argumentation semantics using ASPIC + [16], which is achieved by representing the PDL in ASPIC + (Sections 3.1 and 4), discussing which argumentation preferential relations may be suitable for the conformity of conclusions (Sections 3.2 and 4.1), and proving that the conclusions of the PDL agree under an appropriate preference relationship -SP (Sections 3.3 and 4.2), and that this instantiation is rational (Sections 3.4 and 4.3). As explained in Section 1, this allows us to interpret the conclusions of the PDL as conclusions based on justified arguments and clarify the reasons for adopting or rejecting a conclusion.

sections.heading: 5.1 Related Work
sections.text: As mentioned in Section 1, there are many existing argumentative characterizations of non-monotonous logics (e.g. [11, 12]), but relatively little work has been done using defective rules to represent defaults, since the defeatible components of arguments are often included in the premises [5, 16]. Reiter's Default Logic (DL) [19], as a partial special case 35 of Brewka's PDL [7, sentence 6], has been provided by Dung [11, Section 4.1] with a solid and complete argumentation semantics. DL, however, cannot deal with priorities and consequently draws counterintuitive conclusions. We know that conflicts between defaults occur frequently and priorities are an intuitive and overarching method for resolving such conflicts [7, 8]. It is therefore important to examine how preferences can also be included in any argumentation semantics. ASPIC + is a good framework to achieve this because it is designed in such a way that all defaults are dealt with in the normal case.

metadata.abstractText: We express Brewka’s prioritised default logic (PDL) as argumentation using ASPIC. By representing PDL as argumentation and designing an argument preference relation that takes the argument structure into account, we prove that the conclusions of the justified arguments correspond to the PDL extensions. We will first assume that the default priority is total, and then generalise to the case where it is a partial order. This provides a characterisation of non-monotonic inference in PDL as an exchange of argument and counter-argument, providing a basis for distributed non-monotonic reasoning in the form of dialogue.
